qas.question: What satellite was used when Sky digital was launched?
What satellite enabled Sky Digital to launch an all new digital service?
How many television and radio channels could the new digital service carry?
What is the position of the satellite that allowed sky to broadcast channels almost elclusively for the United Kingdom?
What satellite made it impossible for Sky Digital to launch an all new digital service?
How many television and radio channels did the digital service get rid of?
When was the only satellite launched?

context: When <b5_0>Sky Digital<b5_0/> was launched in <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b8_0>1998<b8_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> the new service used <a1_1>the <a1_0><a1_2>Astra 2A<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> satellite which was located at the 28.5°E orbital position, unlike the analogue service which was broadcast from 19.2°E. This was subsequently followed by more Astra satellites as well as <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b6_0>Eutelsat's Eurobird 1<b6_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> (now Eutelsat 33C) at 28.5°E), enabled the company to launch a new all-digital service, Sky, with the potential to carry <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b7_0>hundreds<b7_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> of television and radio channels. The old position was shared with broadcasters from several European countries, while the new position at <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>28.5°E<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> came to be used almost exclusively for channels that broadcast to the United Kingdom.
